H0.text: who wrote the first declaration of human rights. Ashoka the Great

H1.text: who wrote the first declaration of human rights. Hammurabi

H2.text: who wrote the first declaration of human rights. Aristotle

H3.text: who wrote the first declaration of human rights. Cyrus

A4.text: The United Nations has declared the relic to be an 'ancient declaration of human rights' since 1971, approved by then Secretary General Sithu U Thant, after he 'was given a replica by the sister of the Shah of Iran'.

A5.text: The British Museum describes the cylinder as 'an instrument of ancient Mesopotamian propaganda' that 'reflects a long tradition in Mesopotamia where, from as early as the third millennium BC, kings began their reigns with declarations of reforms.'

A6.text: The Shah of Iran promoted the Cyrus Cylinder as the 'first declaration of human rights' in his 1967 book, The White Revolution of Iran.

A7.text: Bill T. Arnold and Piotr Michalowski comment: 'Generically, it belongs with other foundation deposit inscriptions; it is not an edict of any kind, nor does it provide any unusual human rights declaration as is sometimes claimed.'
